channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The ‘Coming Home’ of Zhang Yimou and Gong Li
item.description: In “Coming Home,” Zhang Yimou examines China’s troubled political past and suggests how to deal with it today. With his legendary muse, Gong Li, playing the central character, the film represents a return to form for the director.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Artist Detained Before Tiananmen Anniversary
item.description: Chinese public security agents have detained Chen Guang, 43, a former soldier turned artist whose experiences during those tumultuous days have become a haunting inspiration for his work.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Chen Guang, in 2009, in front of paintings based on his experiences during the suppression of the Tiananmen Square protests.

item.title: India Ink: A Second Conversation With: Times Now Editor Arnab Goswami
item.description: India Ink follows up with the television journalist, known for his aggressive interviews, after his one-on-one with Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA

item.title: Dalai Lama Urges Outside Inquiry Into Spate of Self-Immolations Among Tibetans
item.description: On a visit to Norway, where he was officially snubbed by officials eager to placate China, the spiritual leader also softened his stance against the suicidal form of protest.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL
item.media:description: The Dalai Lama greeting children from a Buddhist school during his visit to the Nobel Peace Center in Oslo on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Officers Kill Armed Civilians in Yemen Capital
item.description: A United States Special Operations commando and a C.I.A. officer killed two armed Yemeni civilians who tried to kidnap them in the capital two weeks ago, American officials said on Friday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Yemenis gathered at the scene of a bomb blast that targeted a troop carrier near two Western embassies in Sana, the capital, on Friday. The barber-shop shooting happened two weeks ago.

item.title: In High Seas, China Moves Unilaterally
item.description: At least twice in recent years, Beijing has sought to explore the South China Sea but backed down after protests by Vietnam. That good will evaporated this week.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: In Ukrainian City Under Blockade, Citizens Go to Ground, and Below
item.description: Like many in the previously quiet industrial city of Slovyansk, Tatyana Vsevolodovna does not share the political passions of the men who stand at barricades with anti-tank rockets and guns.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neighbors of Tatyana Vsevolodovna (not pictured) talked in her basement, which is stocked with provisions bought in preparation for the outbreak of war.

item.title: Ukrainian Forces Attack Militant-Held Police Station
item.description: At least seven people were killed and 40 were injured as the government battled pro-Russian fighters in the city of Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Firefighters extinguished a blaze on Friday in Mariupol after fighting.

item.title: Brunei Ownership Casts a Shadow on a Beverly Hills Hotel
item.description: Since word spread of the turn in Brunei toward a harsh form of Islamic law by Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah, whose Brunei Investment Agency owns the Beverly Hills Hotel, Hollywood has turned its back on the hotel.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY
item.media:description: Protesters outside the Beverly Hills Hotel, owned by the sultan of Brunei, a nation which will permit the stoning of gays and adulterers by law.

item.title: Death Toll Rising, 2 Sides Sign Pact to End South Sudan War
item.description: The talks, which brought President Salva Kiir and the leader of the rebellion, Riek Machar, face to face, came amid growing international pressure.
item.dc:creator: By BENNO MUCHLER

item.title: A Pulverized Prize Changes Hands, Peacefully, in Syria
item.description: Syrian rebels appeared to have fulfilled their end of a deal with the government to leave their bastion in Homs, but a United Nations official said the refugee crisis was worsening.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: The battered interior of the Um al-Zinar Church in the Old City of Homs was a stop on a military-led tour for the news media on Friday as rebels left.

item.title: World Briefing: Niger: Bodies of 13 Migrants Found
item.description: The bodies of at least 13 migrants from Niger who were abandoned by smugglers in the Sahara last week have been found in southern Algeria, several officials said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing : Afghanistan: British Military to Investigate Photo of Soldier Cavorting Next to Dead Insurgent
item.description: Britain’s Defense Ministry said Friday that it had begun an investigation after graphic photos surfaced appearing to show at least one British service member posing next to the corpse of a Taliban fighter in Afghanistan in 2012.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Work Halted at World Cup Stadium
item.description: Electrical work has been halted at a World Cup stadium under construction in the city of Cuiaba until safety precautions are put in place, labor officials said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing : Italy: Berlusconi Begins His Community Service
item.description: Dodging a scrum of reporters, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy on Friday began serving his sentence for tax fraud at a nursing home outside Milan.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: World Briefing: South Korea: Victims’ Parents Assail President Over Government’s Response to Ferry Accident
item.description: Parents of high school students killed in the capsizing of a South Korean ferry marched on the office of President Park Geun-hye in Seoul on Friday as prosecutors continued to try to determine who was responsible for the accident that killed hundreds of people.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Step Forward Into Past for British Gay Couples: Coats of Arms
item.description: The College of Arms has ruled that married same-sex couples in Britain may combine their heraldic symbols on one shield as generations of heterosexual aristocracy have done.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: African National Congress Draws 62 Percent of the Vote in South Africa
item.description: With ballots from all districts counted, the party led by President Jacob Zuma was only slightly down from its showing in 1994, the year it assumed power in the country’s first democratic election.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: U.K. Finds Way Out of Impasse on Ties to E.U.
item.description: British Euroskeptics are accepting that an early treaty change is neither likely nor necessary in order to change Britain's ties to the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: In Stronghold, a Gandhi Finds the Reception Is More Skeptical than Worshipful
item.description: With a week left before votes are counted in India’s general election, the Indian National Congress is fighting to retain its hold in bastions like Amethi, where Rahul Gandhi visited this week.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi spoke with residents in Amethi on Wednesday.

item.title: Lens Blog: The Real Story About the Wrong Photos in #BringBackOurGirls
item.description: A photographer who worked in Guinea-Bissau to show the dignity and resilience of its people is aghast at how her photographs were used – without her permission – to represent girls kidnapped in Nigeria.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: One of three girls who were photographed by Ami Vitale in Guinea-Bissau in 2000 and whose images have been used — without permission — in the online campaign raising awareness of the recent kidnappings in Nigeria.

item.title: Dispatch: In Rwanda, Finding Echoes of Germany
item.description: I was trying to get some distance from the Holocaust, but I saw uncanny similarities in another genocide.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Rebel Prince Shines a Harsh Light on Morocco
item.description: Prince Moulay Hicham has long been estranged from his royal family, and his new book offering political criticism along with the inside scoop is causing a stir.
item.dc:creator: By AIDA ALAMI
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: “There is no Moroccan exception. It’s an authoritarian regime, that’s all,” said Prince Moulay Hicham El Alaoui.

item.title: India Ink: Rhetoric About Women’s Issues Outpaces Political Progress
item.description: Compared to the discourse surrounding women’s issues in India, women’s progress measured in terms of political participation has been glacial.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE

item.title: From Crimea, Putin Trumpets Mother Russia
item.description: The Russian president traveled to Sevastopol, where he used the anniversary of victory over the Nazis to assert that Moscow had the right to annex the peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, center, and Defense Minister Sergei K. Shoigu, left, reviewed the Russian fleet in Sevastopol on Friday.
